I made a funny thing

4 mecanum wheels on one swerve module oriented so that there is low rotational resistance. Theoretically, you could include suspension or some sort of rocker system.
just wanted to post this because its funny

Trying to imagine a game concept where there is no benefit to having any pushing power. Robots with round chassis and super elastic bumpers, that score points by colliding with field elements. Like pinball.

What about a swerve drive where every module is a differential drive? This would allow for wider swerve modules and more contact area.

On second thought, wouldn‚Äôt a super thin wheel be better? If F = ≈≥N, then wouldn‚Äôt a thin wheel offer a higher normal force for better traction?

image1126√ó519 34.8 KB

That said, wouldn‚Äôt this be completely false? It appears my understanding of physics does not match reality. Please correct me.

</bad math>

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":27,"updated_at":"2024-05-07T04:59:05.873Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":758,"readers_count":757,"score":161.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":465326,"topic_slug":"16-wheel-swerve-drivetrain","display_username":"Marcus Kauffman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/9/599eb63f4b535f4b6b087984ce6b11a11c72053b.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55750,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2141 & 21579. Many hats"},"post_url":"/t/16-wheel-swerve-drivetrain/465326/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3381181,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-07T05:07:03.227Z","cooked":"
mkauffman:

On second thought, wouldn‚Äôt a super thin wheel be better? If F = ≈≥N, then wouldn‚Äôt a thin wheel offer a higher normal force for better traction?

[‚Ä¶]

That said, wouldn‚Äôt this be completely false? It appears my understanding of physics does not match reality. Please correct me.

This is where Theory meets Reality.

In Theory, you‚Äôd be semi-correct: width, and thus contact patch, make no difference to friction force. Provided, of course, that mu is the same‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶which is where Reality steps in and issues Theory with a couple of extra reminders. The extra width increases the area for the tread to interlock with the carpet. (See also: TPU printed wheel treads, etc. Those interlock with the carpet just a little bit‚Ä¶) The extra interlock causes an increase in mu. And that increase in mu causes an increase in friction, which means an increase in traction. The extra width also give better wear resistance which means that increase holds up longer.

By the way: N is not a pressure. It is Normal Force. Area doesn‚Äôt factor in. Number of wheels on the carpet would factor in. Normal Force on any given wheel is (weight of robot)/(number of places the robot is supported by the ground).

One minor critique of the original post: Mecanum wheels in this configuration are more useless than normal. I suggest omni wheels, at least they‚Äôll cause sweet drifting ability.

Careful‚Ä¶ a northern Minnesota team is likely to put them all in one line and make a different kind of inline module‚Ä¶

en.m.wikipedia.org

Rollerblade

Rollerblade is a brand of inline skates owned by Nordica, part of the Tecnica Group of Giavera del Montello, Treviso, Italy. The company was started by Scott Olson (b. 1960), Brennan Olson (b. 1964) and Christopher Middlebrook in Minneapolis as Ole's Innovative Sports; when they sold the company, it became Rollerblade, Inc. and has changed hands over time between Nordica, Benetton Group and Tecnica. Inline-skates had been used for many years by ice speed skaters before they became mainstream. F...
